bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 6, 1900

div1.p: Reed writes of Emilie Lawrence Reed's health. He discusses finances and plans for their house at Keewaydin. He expresses concern over the experiments since they have not yet achieved positive results.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 6, 1900
div1.opener:
a Kiss
for “Doogy”
Love to Miss
Lucy-
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
Dec. 6th 1900.
My sweet, sweet Invalid:
div1.p:
It is
nearly eight o'clock, Thursday
evening- I have just come from
the dinner-table, where we
sat & chatted for more than
an hour after our meal was
finished- By the way, our
soldier cook gave us banana
Ice-cream, -- the first I ever
tasted -- and you can't imagine
how delicious it was- It
seemed to taste somewhat
of strawberry- I suppose it
was due to the flavor of the
“apple” banana, of which it was
made- Our mess is better
than when I came, but its
monotony prevents it from
being as appetizing as one
could wish- Still I always
manage to eat too much, espec-
ially for the little exercise I take-
If I don't look sharp, I, too,
will be coming down with
the gout, like my poor, sweet-
afflicted wifie- Your account
of your little walk to Dupont
Circle and your trying to hobble
back, with so much difficulty,
made me so sad the whole
afternoon- I had thought of
you as recovering rapidly, --
as going to the market for
roses and to the theatre for
fun; but that experience
as afforded by your trip to
Dupont Circle don't look
as if my sweet wifie was
getting along very fast-
still sweetheart, if you can
sleep from nine to seven o'clock,
that is something to be thank-
ful for- I trust that your next
letter will tell me that your
darling foot is much better.
November was a “cracker-Jack”
month for expenses, wasn't it
my joy? I expected as much-
Perhaps December's won't be
quite as much, although Christ-
mas is apt to carry the fig-
ures pretty high. As long as
it was all spent for a good
purpose, it is alright- I sent
you on Monday a check for $258.34,
which will bring your account
to $596.92, and I have sufficient to
increase it to $750.00- so that per-
haps we will start the new year
with $80000. This will be quite
satisfactory, considering the
large amount that we have
expended on Keewaydin during
the present year. If we live
and have good luck, we will in-
crease this $800 to $1800 by Dec.
31st of next year, and then by
May 1902 we can yet begin
on that darling house at
our sweet mountain home.
That is all that I want to
save any money for- Just so
that I can make a delight-
ful home for my two sweet,
sweetest girls- After that has
been accomplished, it can all
go- You just hurry up and
get well, my sweet wifie, and
never mind about the expenses
for November! who wrote
Eben Holden concerning which
you spoke? Mrs. Humphrey
warf? I have never read it-
Do pray get all the books you
want to read, for it is the
greatest of all pleasures-
I am very glad that darling
little heart is going to Anap-
olis for Christmas week- I
know that she will have a very
enjoyable time with Helen,
although I understood her to
say that Helen was going
to spend Christmas in George-
town- Our sweet baby must
be careful about taking the
right train for Anapolis-
I am afraid that my precious
wifie will have a very dull
Christmas all by her sweet
self. It's too bad that her
Mr Mantee can't be there to
make a little fun for her- If
he is not there, it won't be
his fault, however. If I wasn't
doing this work, I would be
at some Military Garrison
where my sweet wifie wouldn't
want to come- I really had
to chuckle over my darling wifie's
fears that somebody might
die in the Camp and bring me
into disgrace- What I begin
to fear is not that somebody
will get sick, but rather that some-
body will not get sick!
Those slight fevers that I men-
tioned in my last letter, didn't
turn out to be anything of im-
portance- Still I am not
discouraged, but shall keep
pegging away, hoping for
better results after a while-
Now, go to bed, my sweet joys,
and dream until morning, and
old Mr Mantee will try to do
the same! Boo! Boo! you Joys.
Friday night - Dec. 7th. What a
wet, dreary day this has been!
Rain, rain, rain, and the heaviest
thickest of clouds have hung
over us -- and last night
was such a beautiful,
moonlit night -- as clear
and beautiful as I ever
saw- We were beginning
to have the dust on the
roads & hence the rain comes
in nicely to lay this and I dare
say that the Cuban Farmers
need it for their winter
crops. It seems funny to
speak of this as winter, when
it is in reality milder than
our may in Washington- I
shouldn't like it always,
as I would long for an oc-
casional cold snap, just to make
one's blood tingle a little bit-
You know, lovie, dear, that I
surprise myself with my
ability to take the cold shower-
baths here, which I do every
morning upon arising- I find
them so refreshing & so awake
-ning, as it were! We must have
one at dear Keewaydin one
of these days.

Saturday morning - 8th. Another
cloudy, blustering day- I am
afraid that the weather in the
U.S. has been smacking of
winter- Do pray, precious
heart, keep wrapped up
warm and don't venture out
when it is cold- How is that
fat, gouty toe anyway? Am
looking for a letter, this morning,
to tell me that my dear little
sufferer is so much better-
Make precious Scholar wrap
up warm, too- Take care of
your darling selves- Kisses and
love & love & kisses for my good sweet,
precious girls-
